Dear Bruce W Mossburg:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
October 26, 2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
(2) The personnel record must contain all of the
following information before employment may occur:
( b) Verification of education.
One of eighteen employee files reviewed did not have verification the employee met
education requirements as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/28/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/17/2022
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
(3) The personnel record shall contain:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member’s
performance within a probationary period or not later
than 6 months after the staff member assumes his or
her current responsibilities. After the initial
evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
Four of eighteen employee files reviewed did not contain written evaluations as
required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/28/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/17/2022
10/26/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 11/12/2021

CPA Rule 400.12214 Compliance with the child protection law
An agency shall comply with the child protection
l aw, 1975 PA 238, MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
Three of eighteen employee files reviewed did not have documentation the agency
was in compliance with the child protection law.
CPA Rule 400.12404 Placement
(6) An agency must document, in the child’s record,
within 7 calendar days after placement, the
information specified in R 400.12417 (1) and all of the
following information:
(a) All the following child characteristics:
(i) Gender identity.
(ii) Race.
(iii) Height and weight.
(iv) Eye color and hair color.
(v) Identifying marks.
(vi) Religious or spiritual preference.
(vii) School status, including grade, last school
attended, and educational program.
Two of seven foster care files reviewed did not have the youth's physical
characteristics documented as required.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) Agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at
a minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as
follows, unless a greater frequency is medically
indicated:
(ii) A physical examination every 14 months.
(2) An agency shall maintain a file documentation
from the medical or dental provider of all medical
and dental care received by a foster child.
Two of seven foster care files reviewed did not have a periodic medical examination
completed within the required timeframe or did not have the completed medical
examination documented in the youth's file as required.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
3

(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(a) Child's name.
(b) Child's date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child's
health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the
child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors
relating to the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster
parent to provide a stable, safe, and healthy
environment for the foster child and the foster
family, including information about siblings who do
not reside in the foster home as provided in federal
law.
(i) Name of the assigned social service worker.
(j) Authorization to provide routine and emergency
m edical care.
Three of seven foster care files reviewed did not contain documentation that all
information required within subsection a-j of this rule was provided to the caregivers
within the timeframes outlined within the rule.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/28/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/17/2022

Placement Preservation/ Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned

FOM 801-03 Medical passports
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child's placement date to the following:
• Foster care provider.
• Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young adult re-entering foster care.
The actual date the medical passport is provided
must be documented in the electronic case
management record.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents, if the child is a
temporary court ward.
Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
At reunification. Subsequent medical passports
are not required after reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider:
At or prior to each placement.
• All medical and mental health professionals to
whom the child is newly referred to and accepted
for treatment and/or services prior to or at the
first scheduled appointment while the foster care
7

case is open, regardless of placement.
Subsequent medical passports are not required.
• Older youth/young adults:
Upon initial independent living placement (youth
age 16 and over).
Upon exiting the foster care system (young
adults age 18 and older).
Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young adult:
Within two weeks of re-entry into voluntary foster
care.
Upon exiting foster care.
Seven of seven foster care files reviewed did not have medical passports and
required signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/28/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/17/2022
IV. TE CHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Be sure to indicate in social work contact if an interpreter was needed and/or
used.
• Additional oversight is needed to ensure timely service plans.
• Annotate on signature line of PATP if document was mailed, emailed, etc.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• There were several closed independent living files that still had an open program
type that should have been closed within 30 days of court jurisdiction ending per
FOM 722-15.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
8

There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. SIR
2022C0112024 was initiated on 9/14/2022 regarding allegations unknown staff
members hit a youth in the face with an object, used inappropriate language
around youth and expressed road rage around youth. The investigation
determined violation of rule 400.12206 staff qualifications. A CAP was approved
on 11/14/2022 and was completed.
The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan in response to the
renewal inspection completed on 9/28/2022 with a corrective action plan approved
on 10/17/2022. During the review the agency had fifteen violations. Nine citations
were noted as repeat violations in the current inspection. During this period under
review the agency noted that overall compliance was impacted, in a part, by
increased staff turnover as well as increased placement issues.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment period reported the agency's difficulty in meeting requirements
during this review period. The Chief Administrator stated challenges to meeting
compliance include short turnaround times for certain documents such as PATP’s
and DHS 1105’s. In addition, difficult cases are becoming more frequent and take
up a lot of time for staff. The previous year CAP has been, in part, successful,
however increased staff turnover during the past year has been challenging as
well as a high number of replacements.
The CA indicated the agency has come up with monitoring activities they feel will
assist with overall compliance. Case managers will utilize calendar reminders for
service plan and PATP signature due dates. New case managers will be matched
with a peer mentor to assist with task completion. The CA expressed confidence
that several areas will improve over the next review period.
Financial Overview
Financial records were reviewed and there were no concerns identified.
Staff Interviews
Interviews were conducted with three staff via telephone. Staff report feeling
supported by the agency. Supervisors are available and coworkers assist as
needed. Staff did not report any concerns or areas of need.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care, licensing and independent living services. All files were
stored securely.
9

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
N/A
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
